deliverables/wallaby/ironic-python-agent.message:
I don't think this (as in creating this file) needs to be done here. There is still the file at deliverables/_independent/ironic-python-agent-builder.yaml where the branch can be created as is for now, and we can officially have it listed on the deliverable reporting and pretty webpages starting in Xena. I guess it is an understatement, we don't care about the webpages as much as putting in a wallaby stable branch and moving forward.

This is also potentially an artificial version bump which is misleading post release, but I've not gone back and looked at where the branch presently is at. If Riccardo says that version is good, then so be it.

Hello Julia,

First thanks for your comment.

Concerning myself here is my point of view.

I'm not fan to create a branch for Wallaby from the independent file, for the sake of clarity and to avoid misleanding I really prefer to officiallize the Wallaby part by using this file, I'm ok to switch the release model and I'm ok to add deliverable to a stable series, however, I want to keep things clear and understandable as much as possible. I'm not fan to artificialize Wallaby deliverables (and Wallaby branches) by using the independent model and its deliverables.

Unfortunatelly creating this file isn't about webpage, its mostly about considering the extended maintainance and EOL phases as soon as possible in this process. Indeed with this file we have no chance to miss this deliverable 18 months later and we reduce the risk introduce inconsistences in few months. In 18 months the release management team's members will surely not the same and as much as possible I don't want to leave inconsistences to future generations, especially if they can be avoided from the beginig. Each inconsistence on series mean gates issues, jobs to reenqueue for the infra team, doing speleology session in the history etc... that's time consuming and painful too...

With this file if new version are needed for wallaby we directly know where to refer for these ones. If I correctly understood you often face issues with stable branches, so, refering to this file will allow to produce specific versions and tags, and even allow you to deal with EM and EOL when the time is right.

The independent file mostly remain for the sake of history.

Following one series mean embrass its full life cycle. 

Without that we will surely face inconsistences  at a moment or another (tagging EM and EOL by example, or again, EOL branches removing by example).

Concerning the version number we can't start a new series with a bugfix version, in other words a minor version is required at least. Also I think that a related tag is needed to avoid inconsistences for Wallaby and observe when the model have been switched back.

Let's wait for other release team member their thinking about this.

This is draft to allow to move further about this topic, I'm ok to produce new patch sets if needed.

Hey Hervé,
I pretty much have the same concerns as Julia, but it seems clear that we don't have a lot of options on how to deal with this, your words make sense.
I was just wondering if we could point the wallaby branch to release 2.6.0 instead https://github.com/openstack/ironic-python-agent-builder/releases/tag/2.6.0
It's the latest release of ipa-builder and it's at a good point in history to cut a stable branch, also not that far in terms of commits (3 from latest change).
Not sure how "illegal" that is :)
I'll also wait for other release team members to chip in
Thanks again for your help

Thanks Hervé, all clear from my side.
I'm good with this change.

Hello Riccardo,

You're welcome.

Branching from an existing tag isn't an issue, branches can be created from where we want.

Concerning the tag, the problem isn't if it is illegal or not, the problem is more to know when it will fail with our tooling and our standardization.

AFAIk we never encountered similar use case (at least which I witnessed).

I dove more deeply in our previous series (wallaby, victoria, ussuri, train, stein, rocky) and I could't found deliverables that hadn't been released during a cycle and that had been branched for this cycle.

By declaring a new version I'm more or less sure that things are aligned with the other deliverables and that our machinery will work without too problems.

Maybe the shortest path is simply to recreate a tag at the same point that 2.6.0 to explicit cut it for Wallaby. AFAIK that isn't an issue to create a tag from the SHA and to base the wallaby branch on this point. Things will be explicit, all pieces will be there, you will get what you need and what you want and our tooling/process will be happy.

The reason behind the new tag is that we need to consider that a series should start with a minor version at least, so if you want to release fixes in few months then a minor version will be mandatory. A bugfix version won't be allowed. As Julia said in is previous comment, this kind of version bump will be misleading post release. Indeed it will be a minor version with only bugfixes inside (potentially). The version number will not reflect changes landed, which is misleading.

Creating a new tag from the same SHA used by 2.6.0 will make that point explicit, won't be a misleading post release, will solve the first minor version need, will allow to properly bump your next bugfix versions if needed.

I'm gonna go to update the SHA that we use here.

Hopefully that these elements will answer your questions and fit your needs.

If you need more details or help do not hesitate to ask more questions we will be happy to help you.

tripleo_common/actions/validations.py.message: pep8: E112 expected an indented block
I think it's better to avoid updating attributes in method. This attribute should be initialized in __init__ instead.

Also, would it be a better idea to accept multiple patterns instead of a single pattern, as is done in multiarch support patch in tripleo-validations ?

https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-validations/commit/9750f945db25d1405312a6df738d7c6aaeb1a7f0

The above patch assumes that image name is formatted in one of the following patterns.

 platform + '-' + arch '-' + basename
 arch '-' + basename
 basename

I know this actually does not happen but this can cause the problem if run method is called repeatedly.

Instead of updating attributes, I would prefer to have a local variable here.

swift/common/db.py.message: I found I was having to pass around dicts to keep a tally on markers, definite and possible tombstones, and I didn't want to make those (transient) statistics attributes of the Broker, so it felt like a class would be useful.

this could prove unnecessary: the 'error' in tombstone estimate, i.e. possible_tombstones, is <= RECLAIM_BATCH_SIZE. If RECLAIM_BATCH_SIZE is << shrink_threshold then we may not need to refine the estimate.

e.g. if shrink_threshold is 100K and batch size is 10K, then without any refinement, we might estimate that objects + tombstones = 100001 and not shrink, when in fact objects + tombstones = 90001 and we could have shrunk.

But, it was fun writing so I'm not ready to delete it yet :) And of course, if batch size increases or shrink threshold decreases then it becomes more useful to refine the tombstone estimate.
NB we used to do this with the same conn as the final _reclaim() call, but now we get another conn.
This seems to be unused.
yep, leftover from previous version, will fix
I wonder if we should just go ahead and do this up in _reclaim -- should be fairly cheap, right?
I was planning to run some more performance measurements, but yes that's certainly an option

DatabaseBroker reclaim is enhanced to count remaining tombstones
after rows have been reclaimed. A new TombstoneReclaimer class is
added to encapsulate the reclaim process and tombstone count.
maybe better to define this once in __init__ than every time through the loop
Done

i guess this could be a template too - whatever looks cleanest I guess...

a reader has to grok bothe and see there's TWO conn.execute each time this method is executed
Done
the behavior of offset here to "push the query off the end" as it were is kind of surprising - I wonder if we should try and put a comment around that query
Done
number_of_tombstones_we_leave_behind = maximum_number_of_tombstones_selected_in_the_batch - the_number_that_our_query_actually_deleted
as 1/2 of the public interface of this class; I bet we'd appreciate a docstring.
Done

What do you think about moving this into _reclaim? It'd be a little more expensive in the replicator (where we don't care about the tombstone count), but I bet sqlite could answer that from what it's still got in memory after that final delete off the end, so IDK that it's *that* expensive.

this little bit here surrounded by the reclaimer looked off at first...

i mean the TombstoneReclaimer *has* self/broker - it must be opening and closing connectoins in .reclaim(), so obviously he could do all this at the end of reclaim using the same connection as the last batch... 

but, I think TombstoneReclaimer ends up looking more focused ... at the cost of an extra get() as conn

I agree, there's potential to encapsulate more in TombstoneReclaimer. I kept it focussed because when used in the sharder I only care about tombstones getting reclaimed and counted (not other stuff). But perhaps there's no harm reclaiming everything in the sharder call too? The trade off is 'only do what I need to do' vs 'more encapsulation'.

I guess TombstoneReclaimer could have:

  reclaim_all (which includes a call to reclaim_tombstones)
  reclaim_tombstones

(and the class would be renamed simply Reclaimer.) But then we'd be passing sync_timestamp into the class only for it to pass it back to broker.reclaim_other_stuff.

I'll leave it as it is, but I'm open to further discussion.

I think I prefer the encapsulation -- the alternative seems (to me) to be accepting a callback, like

 tombstone_reclaimer.reclaim(lambda conn: self._reclaim_other_stuff(
     conn, age_timestamp, sync_timestamp))

and that feels kinda gross.

swift/common/utils.py.message: Should this pick up a tombstones arg?

I found it wasn't needed: meta is updated as a side-effect of getting 
a broker's own_shard_range, whereas tombstones is updated by the sharder after the reclaim
So meta_timestamp becomes the last time we *either* called update_meta() *or* update_tombstones() -- weirds me out a little that we don't know which...
Al pointed out that the only time we call update_tombstones should be shortly after calling update_meta, so the difference in practice should be pretty negligible.

I'm so glad we didn't try to do something like

 params.setdefault('reported', 0)
 return cls(**params)

before!

The DISTRO_NAME is used in several places and basically required to be set.  Currently all the base elements set this, because obviously things like "ubuntu-minimal" and "centos-minimal" know what distro they're building.  It's not DIB_ prefixed because it was considered to be internal and automatically set by the build elements.

DIB_RELEASE will be similar; although most build environments (such as here in CI) will be setting that already to choose between releases.

Probably we could guess this from the incoming container name, and if we can't match that, then error out and tell the user they need to set DISTRO_NAME/DIB_RELEASE
... or ... we have ubuntu-containerfile elements, that set all this for you and choose the right dockerfile/image ...

mariadb/templates/bin/_start.py.tpl.message: why remove this?

I waffle between keeping it and removing it, but ultimately decided that it makes more logical sense to have the leader node set the cluster state to live, instead of relying on the member node(s) to set it.  Keeping it here may be a good failsafe but seems overly duplicate for me, but I can be persuaded otherwise if others have strong sentiment about this.
id prefer to see this retry until success on 409

Each node updates the configmap about every 10s anyway, so infinite retry would actually turn this into another unintentional blocker, seeing that it is already putting it to sleep for 1s before every retry.  I can bump this from 3 to 8, and add some jitter as discussed so in the case of multi-node write collision, it will help to stagger them a little better.
you might want to also add 503 and 500 to this, and maybe a separate one for sslexception.

I believe the desire here is to introduce some minor jitter in sleep time (instead of 1 second, something in the range of 0.8 to 1.2 second, although this range is not hard and fast obviously and is up for debate) and at the same time, also increase the number of retries from 3 to 8 (basically somewhere less than 10 seconds (8*1.2=9.6 second)) so I would like to keep the random function in there along with the extra retries for this purpose.
What is the reason for using a random sleep anyway? Why not just set it to 2 seconds?
time.sleep(time.time_ns() % 10) will make you sleep between 0 - 9 seconds instead of 0.8 to 1.2 seconds though

Could also do something like:

time.sleep(time.time_ns() % 10)

and avoid all the random-ness generation.
Can do time.time() % 2 or 3 as well for decimal waits.

it was originally set at 1 second, the idea here is to use random as a way to inject some minor jitter into the sleep pattern to ensure the pods that are colliding will be sleeping for a slightly different amount of time, so they won't all be continuous sleeping and waking up at the same time to better avoid further collision.

This is going to be a bit fiddly. There are two ways through I can see.

1. Provide a zuul variable that determines whether an environment is used, default to False. Then in the kayobe-config-dev patch, override the jobs to set the variable to True. Once that merges, kayobe CI will break until we set the variable to True.

2. Check whether the environments directory exists and set a fact. This could be factored out into a role to keep it DRY.

In each case, I think it makes sense to define a kayobe_env_config_path variable which has the same meaning as the Kayobe variable, and use that in the tasks below.

Upgrades will need consideration too. The second more dynamic approach might be better at keeping things working when Wallaby becomes the previous release.

distributedcloud/dccommon/endpoint_cache.message: It would be better to wrap this in a call that protected by @lockutils.synchronized(LOCK_NAME).  Since EndpointCache.master_keystone_client is shared among all threads concurrent controller is required.
I prefer 'maybe'.  I never like to commit to an answer.
Looking at it again, there is still a possibility that one thread is calling self.get_cached_master_keystone_client() from above while another one is resetting it to None.

Could we do this with:

EndpointCache.master_keystone_client = None
self.get_cached_master_keystone_client()
Why do you use a different lock?

The reason to use the same lock is to protect the shared resource EndpointCache.master_keystone_client. When re_initialize_master_keystone_client()  is called for the newly added subcloud, get_cached_master_keystone_client() can be called by auditing an existing subcloud.

If I used a shared lock then either get_cached_master_keystone_client() or re_initialize_master_keystone_client() would be executing at a given time. re_initialize_master_keystone_client() is to be called only when a subcloud is added and an exception is raised, whereas get_cached_master_keystone_client() is called for all other cases. Thus, I consider them to be unrelated functions which should use separate locks.
Didn't face any issues during testing on DC-6 so probably a rare scenario? Anyways, I have changed it now. Thanks for highlighting!

neutron_lib/tests/unit/api/test_conversi.message: So this is a change in the API since lower() is essentially being done when it wasn't previously.  And in the other cases as well where '5' is changed to '05'.  At a minimum we should add a release note and/or a change to the API ref doc to denote the format change in the POST and GET, since it will be noticed by someone.  It's potentially breaking the API "contract" so Slawek's comment is maybe apropos.
The "dashed" address you mention is almost a bug, and I wonder if the port is actually usable.  I guess we should have always been enforcing a format from Day 1, or sanitizing as you're doing here.

About the MAC format, there is nothing in the API referred to the formatting. The value should be valid but no format is specified.

1) About the format of each octect, if "5" is stored in the DB instead of "05", that won't work (as reported in the LP). This is the goal of this patch.

If "5" is passed to the API, it will be converted to "05" and compared to "05", that should be stored in the DB.

2) About comparing lower or upper cases, as you mentioned, we are safe because all comparisons are done between strings converted to lower.

3) There is another case not commented: the xx-xx-xx-xx-xx-xx format. This is valid and accepted by Neutron: http://paste.openstack.org/show/804876/
This patch will sanitize both what is stored in the DB and the API input for, for example, listing and filter a port.

We are safe in 1) and 2) cases. If someone has xx-xx-xx-xx-xx-xx values stored in the DB, this patch will break this compatibility. This is why I'll propose a patch to fix that. BTW, this is not a common way to defined MAC addreses.

sysinv/cgts-client/cgts-client/cgtsclien.message: What was the reason for going away from the pci_device_class_acclr() ? The PCI class 0x12 is reserved for "Processing Accelerators": https://pci-ids.ucw.cz/read/PD/12 .  So it may or may not be an FPGA.  In terms of what StarlingX supports in the context of this code, the N3000 FPGA is 0x120000 while the AC100 is 0x120001.  I'm not sure if you intended this value to specifically represent the N3000, and the other one for the AC100, but I think I like the more generic way we were doing it before and just identifying a 'processing accelerator' from the class id.

The test code is geared toward the N3000 because it came first and the automated test does not fully cover the acc100. We could add a __getitem__ to the class and make the test code aware of the number of device classes to test.

Yes, the intention was to associate the value to N3000 only. When I found this code at test_kubernetes.py:

        test_config = {
            'pf_class_id': dconstants.PCI_DEVICE_CLASS_FPGA,
            'pf_vendor_id': dconstants.PCI_DEVICE_VENDOR_INTEL,
            'pf_device_id': dconstants.PCI_DEVICE_ID_FPGA_INTEL_5GNR_FEC_PF,
            'pf_driver': 'igb_uio',
            'vf_device_id': dconstants.PCI_DEVICE_ID_FPGA_INTEL_5GNR_FEC_VF,
            'vf_driver': 'igb_uio'
        }

it seemed to me very specific to N3000 (because values of 'pf_device_id' and 'vf_device_id') and I was afraid about the side reference to another device in situations like that.

Shouldn't this be done after we flush any remaining IO with blockdev --flushbufs on L#72 ? i.e. in remove_scsi_device method
Because this just removes device from multipathd monitoring and doesn't touch device, it should be good to run this command once multipath device is flushed.

-1: In my opinion devices should not be removed from multipathd at this point, and they should be removed *after* we have actually removed them from the system.

I think we should add the call to multipath_del_path right after remove_scsi_device method, and making this call should be conditional to the multipathd running.

If we only remove it when we have multipath_name, we could still run into problems, because paths are always generated in multipathd, even when it doesn't form a multipath.

> -1: In my opinion devices should not be removed from multipathd at this point, and they should be removed *after* we have actually removed them from the system.

I disagree with this because of the following two points.

1. The multipath device has been flushed already at this point and it should be safe to remove its path devices here.

2. After we remove the path devices we can't guarantee that the same device name(like sdb) is not used by any other connection. So removing path after device removal might conflict with simultaneous volume attachment, though I think it's very much rare case.


> I think we should add the call to multipath_del_path right after remove_scsi_device method, and making this call should be conditional to the multipathd running.

I've updated the patch according to the suggestion. Thanks !.

> And I'm still not sure about the consequence if this is successful and and flushing the io[1] or removing the scsi devices[2] fails somehow

If flush or removal of iscsi device fails, then the device is incompletely left even without any change, and we need manual cleanup or retrying detachment.

If we need manual cleanup, only difference made by this change is that the iscsi device is no longer monitored by multipathd. The required clean up steps are same and we need to flush and remove the iscsi device manually.

If we can rerun detachment (for example if volume detachiment from an instance failed), retried detachment triggers path removal again. However because we don't validate its result, the multipath_del_path completes without any failure even the device is already removed from multipathd and subsequent iscsi device flush/removal is executed.

So the change doesn't make any big change in the situation we expect when iscsi device is not properly removed.

-1: optimize the common case where we have multipath_name so we don't have to make an additional command line call.

nit: use `self` instead of `LinuxSCSI`

nit: use named parameter so it's easy to know what False is referring to.

This could lead to something like:

        multipath_running = multipath_name or self.is_multipath_running(
            enforce_multipath=False, root_helper=self._root_helper)

Thanks for useful suggestions. Expecially the optimization looks very smart to me.

If I understood correctly the issue is that multipathd doesn't notice in time that the device has been removed from the system by the time we use it again for a new connection.  Maybe we should mention it here so it's clear for other developers why this forced removal is necessary.

Sorry about that. :-(

In that case we need to change the code to account for that by setting multipath_running to True inside the "if multipath_name:" part and add an else clause to it.

        if multipath_name:
            with exc.context(force, 'Flushing %s failed', multipath_name):
                self.flush_multipath_device(multipath_name)
                multipath_name = None
                multipath_running = True
        else:
            multipath_running = self.is_multipath_running(
                enforce_multipath=False, root_helper=self._root_helper)
that's even better  :-)
